bibl.title: Despatch from R.N. Nasson to A. Perrot Esq., November 20, 1866
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
Dear Sir,
Permit us to address you as the representative and guardian of American interest on this part of the West Coast of Africa; and represent to you the great desirability of the presence of an American squaron here. There was a navy here before the war, and it ought to be nestered since the Government is now so able and has such an abundance of vessels. If you take testimony from the Gaboon missionaries and traders, they will confirm what I hear and believe at Kamba, that all along this coast small vessels still carry on a slave-trade wuith Or Thomas and
Princes islands, uncharted by the Spanish or French government. The recent robbery in the Muni-- the robbery to which I was subjected among the Bapaka the shooting of younf Maclachlin of Kamba has been unpunished by either English <pb facs="20170615_113445"
or Spanish or French; and these are not the first acts of the kind that have you unpunished..
T
he dignity of our Government ought to leave some effeicent sign of power you will excuse the word effecient . You are a sign of our Government power, but you will acknowledge yourself helpless without a flag or a national ship.--
I present there for suggestion with the earnest wish that you will address the Department on the subject. It would be a great joy to our eyes if we could monthly see the American flag passing along this coast.
Accept, dear Sir, sentiment of regards and believe me very truly yours-- Signed R.N.Nassan
